b'The iconic Riverfront Park in Downtown Spokane is the perfect place to get out of the house and get some fresh air. Visit on a Friday, Saturday or Sunday at sunset and watch the Pavilion at Riverfront come to life during one of its free, dynamic light shows.

Pro tip: Don\xe2\x80\x99t forget your mask! Face coverings are required at indoor and outdoor public spaces in the state of Washington.

Photo: @travelthroughrodric'

b"We're suckers for a good sunset, and Moab has some of the best.\n\n@wherekatieis's favorite is at Dead Horse Point State Park. Her tip for first timers: Get there about an hour before sunset so you can get a good spot, set up and enjoy the views."

b'"Thankful to Delta for providing peace of mind during this global pandemic along with complimentary drinks, upgrades, bags, vacant seats beside every person, hand sanitizer, seat wipes, and smiles!" - @skylar777, Gold Medallion Member\n\nReady to welcome you back to the skies with peace of mind.'

b'Last weekend marked the end of an era for the iconic 777 fleet. While we celebrate the memories it helped us create over the past two decades, we look ahead \xe2\x80\x93 as we pull the future of our fleet forward - to the adventures to come.\n\nPhoto: @khhycl'

b'"Now more than ever I\xe2\x80\x99m incredibly proud to be a Delta employee and Flight Attendant and let me tell you why...

A few weeks ago Delta officially launched a new internal initiative for Flight Attendants called the Diversity, Equity & Inclusion (DE&I) program and I just received my uniform pin indicating that I am a DE&I Ally!

The goal of the program is to have allies spark compassionate and thought-provoking conversations between employees in an effort to understand each other more and empathize with the struggles that some employees face that others might not.

Although this program just launched, Delta has held quarterly Diversity & Inclusion forums for Flight Attendants for years and began work on this program long before the recent tragedies that sparked worldwide outrage and increased dialogue about how Black lives are treated in our society.

This commitment to true change is what makes me extra proud to be a Delta employee and I\xe2\x80\x99m incredibly honored to be a small part of the journey to becoming a better, more compassionate, more empathetic and more just workplace and society." - Noah K. - Flight Attendant, #JFK

The vulnerability we all feel at the confluence of the pandemic and racial injustice happening across our world is real. By listening and learning, we can better understand one another and our individual experiences to help move towards a stronger, more equitable future.'

b"One of our favorite jets. What's yours?"

b'"While traveling may have changed this year and social distancing has us staying apart...remember to get out and see what the world has to offer. 

Share these moments and experiences with those who may not be able to get out and explore for themselves, for we are all human and should never be starved of adventure and nature."

Photo: Thomas L. - Aircraft Maintenance Technician, #SAN'

b'"I am proud to be a first-generation, Paisa (which means I\xe2\x80\x99m from Medellin), Colombian-American, ATLien Latina. It took me over 20 years to become a U.S. Citizen. Immigration documentation and lawyer fees, time, travel restrictions, academic limitations, emotional and psychological stressors, major personal life changes were the price my family and I paid to have the right to use our voice and submit our ballots. Having experienced the journey to naturalization and becoming a U.S. citizen, voting is not just a right in our family \xe2\x80\x93 it\xe2\x80\x99s our responsibility. I recognize the hard work that has been done by others to ensure that, as a woman of color, I have the right to vote, and it\xe2\x80\x99s up to us to protect it.

I am forever grateful for this country and for the life my family and I are living and continue to build, so voting is just one way I can show gratitude. I\xe2\x80\x99m voting for those who fought for our right to have a voice, for those who lack the privilege to and for those whose voices are yet to be heard. Whatever your reason is, I encourage you to vote!" - Juanita V. - Marketing Manager, #ATL

The stories of where we're from help shape us into the people we are today and voting gives us an opportunity to help shape the world around us. This year, we encourage you to make your voice heard  because no matter what language you speak or what you believe in, we all share the same goal to make the world a better place.'
b'A seat with a view.\n\nPhoto: David G. - Ramp Agent, #ATL'
b'Leaving on a jet plane.\n\nPhoto: Javon S. - Customer Service Agent, #LAX'

b'"What do I love the most about October? Getting to raise money and offer support to all of these amazing people who have battled and continue to battle breast cancer. This uniform already means so much to me, but to also be able to accessorize in all pink is heaven! I love hearing the stories and personal experiences from survivors regarding their journey and path to overcoming their challenges and struggles.

I'm also ecstatic and encouraged by the thousands that are currently fighting and living each day as if it were their last. There is so much optimism and hope nowadays as we strive another day closer to a cure. For those currently: stay strong, stay positive, stay blessed, and kick cancer's butt! You are much stronger than you think." - Jonathan S. - Flight Attendant, #JFK

In this family, no one fights alone. Join us and donate to @BCRFcure at the link in our bio to support life-saving research.'

b'\xe2\x80\x9cMy Latinidad is not only what I check off on the Census every 10 years, but as I have gotten older it has turned into how I interpret my life every day. Being first generation brought a whole new level of challenges to my identity growing up. Yet they made me who I am today, a proud Afro-Latina with roots dating back to the Taino Indigenous People of Dominican Republic. 
 
As a young girl, I hid from the thought of having a strong accent, so I watched the news to perfect a more 'acceptable' one. This caused a lot of people to never realize I was Latina until I mentioned it. I used to be embarrassed, but as I grew older I learned to respect, admire and feel proud of my accent, just as the Latinos in my family and community showed me. I learned that having an accent doesn\xe2\x80\x99t take away from our community\xe2\x80\x99s hard work, dedication and extremely focused and driven mentality, which seems almost instinctual in our people. It adds the complexity of being able to communicate with people from other places. I carry that thought with me every day, so when I encounter folks who find out that I\xe2\x80\x99m Latina and make the comment \xe2\x80\x98oh you speak English very well,\xe2\x80\x99 I say to them, \xe2\x80\x98and I speak Spanish very well too, those are my bilingual talents\xe2\x80\x99."
 
Being proud of who you are inspires those you meet along the way to be authentic to their identity. When we let go of the fear of being our full selves, the world can see the beauty inside each of us.'
b'Who needs a video call background when you can see it in person?\n\nPhotos: @tsode (PLS), @travelwander.lust (AMS), @yourbasefare (SLC), @voyagermd (DEN)'
b'The only thing better than a sunrise at home is a sunrise while traveling.\n\nPhoto: Michelle A. - Red Coat, #PBI'

b'Itching to get out and explore the world again? When you\xe2\x80\x99re ready to fly, try someplace away from the crowds where you can hike for miles without seeing a soul. Delta employee Andrew says Anchorage is one of his favorite places to visit because it's the perfect combination of peaceful and adventurous.

"Being in nature is one of the easiest ways to escape and socially separate during the pandemic. Alaska has very clear and specific regulations to enter the state and I felt very safe there, as people were respectful in following those guidelines."

Photo: Andrew B. - Flight Attendant, #MSP'
b'New terminal, who dis?\n\nPhoto: @senior.living.adventures'

b'"Being Latino in New York means you are surrounded and influenced by our community's diversity. My Latinidad is unique because of how I\xe2\x80\x99ve embraced all other Latin American cultures.
 
I live on a block where Mexicans, Puerto Ricans, Colombians, Ecuadorians and Cubans also live. I have tasted the homemade Mexican Mole, Puerto Rico\xe2\x80\x99s infamous Pernil, Colombia\xe2\x80\x99s flagship dish in NYC 'La Bandeja Paisa,' Ecuador\xe2\x80\x99s top of the line Ceviche de Camaron and Cuba\xe2\x80\x99s Frijoles Negros con Mariquitas. My mouth is watering just thinking about it. 

The music of each country has immensely influenced my upbringing as well. I often listen to Rancheras, la Salsa, my Merenguitos sabrosos, Vallenatos de sentimiento and Cumbia. 
 
As I travel to different countries around the world, I know that not everyone will understand my culture, even if we speak the same language. However, if you are open to accepting that our differences can add and not subtract, you will always have the opportunity to reinvent yourself." - Ernie P. - Sales Account Executive, #NYC

The more of the world you see, the more you understand that everyone's different cultures, heritage and traditions are what makes it beautiful.'
b'Flying over the Windy City never gets old.\n\nPhoto: @flyingahmvd'

b"Our key priority is keeping you safe throughout your trip, including at the gate and while boarding. We've updated our procedures to give you more space, cleaner surfaces and reduced contact with other customers.\n\nTo find more info on each layer of protection we're putting in place, tap the image and click on an account."

b'"Traveling means everything to me. It\xe2\x80\x99s a chance for me to open my mind and eyes to all those around me. I\xe2\x80\x99m grateful for traveling because I\xe2\x80\x99ve found a deeper appreciation for diversity, cultures & all this beautiful world has to offer." - @d.giordano_, SkyMiles Member\n\nWhat has traveling helped you appreciate?'

b'"Delta, I am loyal to you forever.

1. I love my SkyMiles card
2. They provided me with snack packs 2-3 times on each of my flights! Thx for all the KIND snack bars and Dasani waters!
3. I was handed sanitizing wipes on entry and there were single-use Purell hand sanitizer packs in the snack bags.
4. Only two to a row max, and you adjusted how you boarded the plane.

:raising_hands_medium-light_skin_tone::folded_hands_medium-light_skin_tone: WELL DONE. Points for you, Delta." - @wanthoneywiththat, SkyMiles Member

From the moment you check in to when you return home, we want you to feel safe, comfortable and at ease at every point in your journey.'

b'Our journey of listening and learning continues as we amplify the diverse voices of our Latinx employees. We're celebrating and honoring the myriad of identities, cultures, languages and traditions that makeup this vibrant community.
 
"I grew up in Puerto Rico, my mom always had this passion for travel and exploring new corners around the world. Because Puerto Rico is the only Latin American territory with a U.S. passport, this allowed me to explore the world in unique ways, being able to travel to places I could never imagine. 

I\xe2\x80\x99ve always tried to explore the world in a non-touristic way; learning and appreciating other countries\xe2\x80\x99 histories, diverse cultures, and traditions. However, as a Puerto Rican, language barrier has always been a challenge for me. My English is very different from what I've seen around the world. I have a very strong accent and everyone I talk to, anywhere I go, the first question I always get is, 'where are you from?'

I recall several times not being able to communicate at all, it can be frustrating to feel like you\xe2\x80\x99re not getting your message across. One of the worst experiences was when I took a ride share in a new country I\xe2\x80\x99d never visited before, it was midnight and to top it off, I accidentally put the wrong address in the app. 

I was trying to explain to the driver that this was not the place I was looking for, but he became frustrated with me because he couldn\xe2\x80\x99t understand my English. He told me to get out of the car and left me in the middle of nowhere and I didn\xe2\x80\x99t have access to Wi-Fi anymore. After 30 min of desperately walking down that street, I found a local bar. The owner was very helpful, I told him I was from Puerto Rico and luckily, he knew a little bit about 'mi isla' and showed me how to get back to the hotel.

I\xe2\x80\x99ve always found compassion from people that want to learn from my culture as well, learn a few words in Spanish or share experiences with me. It makes me feel welcomed and appreciated." - Adrian T. - Supply Attendant Tech Ops, #ATL'

b"The lives and voices of our Black employees, customers and the communities we serve matter. That's why when JFK Flight Attendant Antonio D. suggested introducing Delta-sponsored Black Lives Matter pins, we made them available for our employees.\n\nPhoto: Seth M. - Flight Attendant, #ATL"

b'"I am finishing a trip from Seattle to Boston and New York, and it is so wonderful to be here at 38,000 feet after five months of not flying. This Delta One 757 flight is terrific, and the views from up here never get old.

I\xe2\x80\x99m grateful to the awesome Delta Flight Attendant in the business class cabin for making this such a great experience! Delta has gone above and beyond to make flying as safe and hygienic as possible for passengers - and their effort is abundantly clear from check-in to landing." - @phil_in_flight, Diamond Medallion Member

You deserve peace of mind while you travel.  So when you\xe2\x80\x99re ready to fly, know that a safer, cleaner and more flexible experience is waiting.'

b'"I remember my first day at Delta Air Lines as I walked through the Flight Attendant Training Center halls. That\xe2\x80\x99s right, after receiving an undergraduate degree from Hampton University, I joined Delta as a Flight Attendant. That first day filled me with a range of emotions: the excitement in starting a new career, the uncertainty of being accepted, and an insane pressure to succeed. As my career progressed, I began to take these emotions as a condition of being a Black woman in corporate America.
 
Acceptance is a universal desire, but being an ambitious, working woman in corporate America creates additional pressures, including the likelihood of isolation and failure. Add the blessing of being African American, and you have a greater probability of not achieving your goals.

More than once, I've been guilty of shrinking myself to allow others to feel more comfortable. It can be exhausting, surfing through the constant advice women often receive: \xe2\x80\x9cSpeak up." "Ask for what you want." "Earn your seat at the table." while also hearing "Don\xe2\x80\x99t be aggressive, or sharp or too direct, you don\xe2\x80\x99t want to be seen as intimidating." 

With maturity has come the confidence to embrace my authentic voice. There are still moments when I reflect on all the advice, particularly when I may be the \xe2\x80\x9conly one\xe2\x80\x9d in the room. Now, these reflections reinforce a need to be true to me versus working to fit someone else's idea of how a woman should show up.
 
My advice? Use every new suggestion to further define your authentic self, then get to work. We have to play an active role in creating the working world we know we deserve." - Sandy G. - SVP of Airport Operations

Here's to the disruptors, shakers and powerhouses that fuel our engines. We're lucky to have Sandy as a pillar of our business, and know the work is not done in becoming a more just and equitable company for all.'
b'Ready to welcome you back on board.\n\nPhoto: Noah K. - Flight Attendant, #JFK'

b'"What I\xe2\x80\x99ve learned throughout my travels is that, no matter where I am, I am seen as a representative of Black-American culture. Oftentimes, when I meet new people in different countries, I\xe2\x80\x99ve found that the best way they can connect with me is through music, food, and what they perceive to be 'Blackness.'
 
I recall a time I was eating with a group of fellow travelers. We were talking about the kinds of music we love to dance and listen to. I talked about how I loved music that was birthed out of the Caribbean, like Dancehall, Reggae, Bachata, and Zouk. As someone raised by Jamaican-immigrant parents, this is the type of music that has always felt like home. However, this seemed to take everyone at the table by surprise. One guy even said, 'I assumed you would\xe2\x80\x99ve said Rap music, like Tupac and Biggie.'
 
This experience reminded me that many people\xe2\x80\x99s proximity to Blackness is really based on what they\xe2\x80\x99ve seen through media. Black people are not a monolith, and we all have different experiences and interests. That\xe2\x80\x99s the beauty of the African diaspora. Whether you\xe2\x80\x99re a Black European, a Black African, a Black Latino, Black West Indian or Black American, our Blackness is and should be defined by our individual experiences and not what others perceive them to be. 
 
To me, listening is the best thing anyone can do to understand someone\xe2\x80\x99s point of view and challenge your own ideas, misconceptions, and assumptions.. If we're all able to practice this in our everyday lives, we\xe2\x80\x99ll see fewer differences and more love and unity." - Jayde P. - Senior Analyst, #ATL

Traveling gifts us the opportunity to connect through shared experiences and expand the way we recognize unconscious biases. Only when we listen to learn can we grasp the true meaning of human connection.'
b"Window or aisle seat? Let's debate. :backhand_index_pointing_down: \n\nPhoto: @flyhigh717"
b"We don't know who needs to hear this, but we're sanitizing our planes between every flight, every day, everywhere."
b'Name that airport.\n\nPhoto: @firstclass1a'
b'Ready to get out of the house like...'

b'"I'm an endless wanderer. Travel leaves a powerful imprint on my heart and soul and I always leave a little piece of me behind. It opens my eyes to the unknown so that I can constantly learn and grow as an individual. I can not imagine my life without it!

I still have goals and dreams that go way beyond the life of the ordinary. Looking forward to numerous spontaneous adventures and the lifelong memories of traveling somewhere new to inspire myself and others!" - @mytravelexcuses, Gold Medallion Member

What inspires you to travel?'

b"We know flying may seem a little overwhelming right now. Between masks, social distancing and staying safe, there's a lot to think about. Rest assured, we've thought of everything you need to stay safe while traveling, so all you'll have to do is enjoy your trip - that's the Delta CareStandard.\n\nTo see each layer of protection we've put in place for you on board, tap the image and click on an account to find more info."
b'Raise your hand if you need a vacation. :person_raising_hand:\n\nPhoto: @katelacey'

b'"One of my first experiences overseas was traveling to a country far from my home.
 
During my stay, I've learned that it\xe2\x80\x99s quite uncommon for a young Black woman to travel this far. A lot of the questions raised were, \xe2\x80\x9cAre you an athlete?\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cAre you in the military?\xe2\x80\x9d At first it seemed as if I had to have some type of high status or specific profession to be abroad, as if the standard of travel is non-Black. Over time, I saw that I was more of a curiosity because of my appearance.
 
Being a Black traveler doesn\xe2\x80\x99t necessarily mean you have to be elite to be able to travel the way that others do. Black people work just as hard to have the same opportunities by becoming doctors, lawyers, or even Delta Flight Attendants.
 
Travel doesn\xe2\x80\x99t have an age, color, or religion. It\xe2\x80\x99s open for the world to see and experience. I\xe2\x80\x99ve always been told by friends and colleagues to see the world and to not let fear get in the way. My recommendation when traveling is to have an open mind to trying and learning new things in order to embrace cultural diversity." - Vanessa M. - Flight Attendant, #ATL

Understanding the experiences people who are different from us face is key in the bridging of communities. Only when we embrace our similarities and celebrate our differences, can we truly shape the world to become a more welcoming place.'
b'Masked up. Peace up. Wheels up.\n\nPhoto: @samantharraae'
b'A beacon of hope.\n\nPhoto: @propelphysio'

b'The fight for racial equality continues, and we're continuing to elevate our Black employees' stories. Through listening to those who look, feel or think differently than us, we can truly better connect the world.

"While traveling I\xe2\x80\x99ve experienced many challenges that sadly, have become the norm to me now. On more than one occasion I\xe2\x80\x99ve had people cross the street or turn back and go the other way.
 
I recall one specific instance where I was walking on the street and noticing people staring and making every effort possible to avoid me. At first, I didn\xe2\x80\x99t think much of it, until a local gave me insight and told me those people didn\xe2\x80\x99t want anything to do with me. He explained to me that it was because I was a Black foreigner and began apologizing for their actions. He assured me that not everyone there is like that and offered assistance.
 
I have found compassion from people around me when they listen to understand, not just listen to react or counter what I expressed. I believe if others replicate that simple task we will see a lot more progress." - Marlon D. - First Officer, #JFK'

b'"Haven\xe2\x80\x99t been on a plane in 5 months, and I have to say, it feels good to be flying right now. Masks, social distancing, and safety for the win. Thank you, @delta, for making this such a pleasant experience. :folded_hands_medium-light_skin_tone::blue_heart::airplane_selector:"

Everyone's travel experience should be a safe one. It's that simple.

Photo: @robinrandolph'

b'"Travel means everything to me. It's the journey of going somewhere that changes you for the better by giving you new experiences. Nothing makes me happier than getting on a plane, knowing I am about to get out of my comfort zone, explore new places, meet locals, embrace new cultures and return home with amazing memories.

I miss going somewhere new and returning home, feeling like a piece of my heart is still there. I can\xe2\x80\x99t wait to get back to traveling and exploring more of this beautiful world." - @travelsizedsandler, Diamond Medallion Member

What do you look forward to most about exploring the world again?'
b'Fly forward and never look back.\n\nPhoto: Andy C. - First Officer, #LAX'
b'Fly forward and never look back.\n\nPhoto: Andy C. - First Officer, #LAX'

b"Our smiles may be a little harder to see these days but they're still there - we promise!

Photos: Sarah C. - #ATL
Micah G. - #MSP
MiQuel M. - #JFK"
b'Are you an A350, 777 or something else? Find out at @whatplaneyouare :eyes: ...and comment below if we missed your name!'
b'"Over 60,000 miles traveled last year. Can\'t wait to get back to views like this one."\n\nWe\'re ready when you are, @renerodr23.'

b'\xe2\x80\x9cSociety says I have three strikes against me before I even say a word. Black. Female. Lesbian. The reality is there will be people who will not like me or feel comfortable around me based on my skin color. There will be people who judge me based on the love I have built with my wife. I have endured the stares of strangers while on layovers in cities that are not as diverse. The snickers of others as my wife and I hold hands in the grocery store. We are fighting to have a place in this world that accepts and acknowledges our differences.
\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80
The past few months have been especially trying for all of us. I have had coworkers reach out to me personally to ask how they can better support me and the Black community. They have been so open to learning and asking questions to gain insight and that has meant a lot to me.

What makes me most proud about being Black, female and lesbian is the fact that those pieces of me are derived from three groups who have fought so hard to be seen and heard. There is still work to be done for all three communities to get the unconditional love and support we all deserve. I am personally surrounded by a village of individuals that see me and love me, for that I am beyond thankful.\xe2\x80\x9d - Megan M. - Flight Attendant, #ATL

A lot looks different this year, but the fight for justice is just as important as ever. We still have a long road towards equality, and we\xe2\x80\x99re committed to using whatever means we have to move the world toward a better, more just tomorrow.'
b'The world has been waiting for you. So have we.\n\nPhoto: @alexleevisuals'

b'The injustices we\xe2\x80\x99ve recently seen remind us that diversity and equality shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t only be talked about by underrepresented populations \xe2\x80\x93 but by all.

This week, we hosted a company town hall where CEO @edbastian sat down with lawyer, activist and author Bryan Stevenson to discuss his experiences dealing with racism and social injustice, and the important work he\xe2\x80\x99s doing at @eji_org.

Let\xe2\x80\x99s talk about it: how can you be a good ally? Comment below, then head to our Stories to see what our employees had to say.'

b'\xe2\x80\x9cTravel is fearlessness. It takes bravery to completely immerse yourself into the unknown and allow yourself to embrace it. Travel allows us the opportunity to step outside of what we know and experience something truly diverse. Every new experience, every moment, and every adventure stays with us. It almost changes our DNA and has the unequivocal ability to shape us in ways we did not think were possible.

The Grand Canyon is one of those places that forces you to really pause and appreciate the natural beauty of the world. I sat there for some time wondering if what I was seeing was real or just an illusion. Earth is pretty awesome and I cannot wait to explore and photograph more heart-stopping places like this!\xe2\x80\x9d - @sashprez, SkyMiles Member

Where will you travel to next?'

b'"Growing up with my Black, Asian, Latino and white family and being surrounded with friends from different backgrounds has provided me with a sense of embrace for all humanity because I learned to appreciate what makes people different, unique, intriguing, interesting and inspiring.

The world has seen amazing athletes, singers, actors, poets, doctors, lawyers and leaders face bias and prejudice due to the color of their skin. Imagine adding an additional layer of bias by being part of the LGBTQ+ community. Even within the LGBTQ+ community, sometimes there is a disconnect between race relations and ethnic backgrounds. I, myself, have been judged because of these disconnects.

I\xe2\x80\x99ve been able to get the most amazing support by communicating with my family, coworkers, friends and allies. Even if it\xe2\x80\x99s hard or uncomfortable to discuss the \xe2\x80\x9chow\xe2\x80\x9d in the Black and LGBTQ+ world, the end product of candid conversations is a higher level of understanding that can only drive one thing: change." - Christian A. - Care Concierge Specialist, #ATL

Being a global airline means we are a global family. A family made up of every race, gender and orientation. Because no matter where you're from, how you identify or who you love, the world where we show our true selves is the world we'll keep on connecting.'

b'"I have been socially distancing away from family due to the pandemic. I could no longer go without seeing my adult kids, so I made the tough choice to end my isolation with a visit to Atlanta.

I parked my car at the Jacksonville airport. Upon walking in, I realized I had left my cell phone (also access to my ticket) in my parked car. Panicking, I approached the Delta check-in counter and asked if I could use a phone, explaining my predicament.

I was almost in tears when a lovely woman named Lenita with Delta offered her phone to me. Overhearing my problem, a gentleman behind the counter named Bryan with the Delta IT department came to the rescue, offering to drive me to the lot to retrieve my phone. He in all likelihood saved me from missing my plane and seeing my children!

He was so professional and kind. He not only drove me to the lot but waited for me and drove me back to the airport. I can not rave enough about the kindness I experienced from these individuals, even in such distressing times." - Lori F. - SkyMiles Member, #JAX

We know it's about more than getting from point A to point B - it's the kindness along the way.'
b'To the families celebrating together, or those missing Dad from afar, Happy Father\xe2\x80\x99s Day from our Delta family to yours.'

b'"Juneteenth represents a bold proclamation of limitless opportunities - a belated liberation that solidifed the emancipation of the quarter million enslaved people without freedom. \xe2\x81\xa3
\xe2\x81\xa3
Traveling provides me the space to exercise my own freedom \xe2\x80\x94 no matter the destination, I can embark on a journey of my choice and unlock endless possibilities created by my own intent. \xe2\x81\xa3
\xe2\x81\xa3
It has given me the opportunity to gain an understanding & appreciation for different cities, countries and cultures \xe2\x80\x93 but it also means that, at times, I find myself being the first Black person someone has encountered outside of television & magazines. \xe2\x81\xa3
\xe2\x81\xa3
In these situations (usually in small, rural cities) I receive intense stares; I can feel their eyes explore the color of my skin and watch them visually touch the texture of my hair with their pupils. Some even point with their fingers. It can be quite overwhelming and uncomfortable. \xe2\x81\xa3
\xe2\x81\xa3
In moments like these I remind myself that traveling is two-sided and rooted in understanding. Not only am I fortunate to increase my global awareness by taking in new experiences, but traveling provides a sacred opportunity to share my identity & culture with the world. \xe2\x81\xa3
\xe2\x81\xa3
I can celebrate other\xe2\x80\x99s uniqueness while being proud of my own. That is the spirit of Juneteenth.\xe2\x80\x9d - Jamar H. - Network Planning MBA Associate, #ATL \xe2\x81\xa3
\xe2\x81\xa3
Travel connects us to the best of humanity, but also exposes us to truths we sometimes cannot see on our own. By learning, listening and acting we can courageously share our full selves and connect with others who don\xe2\x80\x99t look like us, act like us, or think like us.'

b'"Yesterday was the first time flying in over three months and I\xe2\x80\x99ve missed it. I will honestly say that Delta did an awesome job making me feel safe."\n\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\nGreat to have you back, @tybuckingham.'

b'"It\xe2\x80\x99s crazy how the freedom of simply going outside is something we are currently realizing we shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t take for granted.

Travel is one of my favorite things to do. I love to explore the world and learn about new cultures. I am grateful for traveling because it gives me the chance to try new things, meet new people, and experience things that I wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be able to experience in my hometown.

As you continue to go through life and experience people, you just have to find the silver lining. It\xe2\x80\x99s the only way to get through this." - @themillennial_ceo, Silver Medallion Member

What has travel allowed you to experience?'
b'The best moments always come after the storm.\n\nPhoto: Sabrina B. - Flight Attendant, #ATL'
b'Cleared for takeoff.\n\nPhoto: @heilingadventures'

b'"Today is so bittersweet, it\xe2\x80\x99s the last time I will work and board the MD88/90 before we officially retire our remaining McDonnell Douglas fleet.
\xe2\x81\xa3
This fleet holds a lot of firsts for myself and many of my colleagues & for that I am forever grateful. My first service flight in training, my first trip I ever flew as working crew to Montego Bay, 7 years ago, and many many more.
\xe2\x81\xa3
Mad Dog, thank you for being the 'workhorses' for this company. We will miss you dearly. :red_heart_selector::airplane_selector:" - Haley S. - Flight Attendant, #ATL

Earlier this week we bid farewell to the MD-88 and MD-90, but the contributions of these aircraft to our past and future will last forever.

Photos: @diecastryan, @Drew_Fellers_Studios'

b'Our commitment will always be to connect the world around us. We can\xe2\x80\x99t achieve that goal without acknowledging that people are hurting, and as a result that pain, frustration and justified anger can make those connections feel more distant than ever.
\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80
Words alone cannot help to solve the crimes of racism. We recognize that we still have work to do, but know that we are listening and will not be silent.

The lives of our Black employees, customers and community partners matter. We will use whatever means we have to ensure that the world we see now, tomorrow and in the future is a world that is just.'

b'"You will often hear me say, 'Travel gives me life!' and I truly mean that in every sense. I want to experience life, not just mine in the United States, but life around the world.
\xe2\x81\xa3
Travel isn't about how many great photos I can take, it's the feeling of being someplace new and immersing myself in the culture and exploring the unknown. It is an incredible feeling to see the world through my own eyes and meet all the wonderful people in these places along the way." -@theblonderer, Gold Medallion Member

What are you looking forward to experiencing next?'

b'"The aviation life is our only life. COVID changed so much of what our family life looked like and while not in the way we would have chosen, this time forced us to cherish every moment.\xe2\x81\xa3
\xe2\x81\xa3
While at home, my daughter became an avid and rather stylish "flive attentat" and my son's vivid memories of being in the cockpit and touring the airport still live through our quarantine chats.\xe2\x81\xa3
\xe2\x81\xa3
We never miss a family breakfast, we camp out in the backyard, we count stars at night and kiss each other goodnight every single day, and we still dress up for work in our purple Delta uniform."
\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80
A great reminder to cherish every moment with loved ones, no matter the situation. When you\xe2\x80\x99re ready to create new memories with those you\xe2\x80\x99ve missed, we\xe2\x80\x99re here to connect you.
\xe2\x81\xa3
Photo: Carla B. - Base Manager, #JFK\xe2\x81\xa3'

b'Amid the challenges that COVID-19 has presented, the important work of the Delta Honor Guard has continued. The Delta Honor Guard is a volunteer group of employees dedicated to caring and honoring fallen soldiers during their travels home. When a solider is transported to their final resting place, they are met by family, military personnel and the Delta Honor Guard, who march with flags from all five military branches.\xe2\x81\xa3
\xe2\x81\xa3
For over 15 years, Atlanta employee Brian has led our Honor Guard ceremonies showing respect to those who have made the ultimate sacrifice. Brian has continued to make sure these honorable moments continue when our fallen heroes arrive, so they receive a proper ceremony for their service to our country. \xe2\x80\x9cI feel honored to be able to serve on the Honor Guard team and take this responsibility as if it was my own family member. It\xe2\x80\x99s a sobering experience to stand in tribute, but it\xe2\x80\x99s our way of serving our country and ensuring our heroes are well cared for on their journey home.\xe2\x80\x9d - Brian, Honor Guard Coordinator - #ATL \xe2\x81\xa3
\xe2\x81\xa3
To all the fallen heroes who have fought for our freedom, thank you.'

b'This isn\xe2\x80\x99t a regular gin drink. This is a Bramble Tonic. If you\xe2\x80\x99re looking for a refreshment you can make at home, you\xe2\x80\x99ll want to grab this recipe.\n\nHead to our highlights to learn how to recreate another one of our favorite Delta Sky Club drinks!'

b'"After seeing my mother in law for Mother\xe2\x80\x99s Day, I started to ache for my own family. Ache to be outside these 4 walls of my home.

Travel is the opportunity to form deep meaningful connections with both people and places all over the world. The kind of connection that forever changes your heart. Travel helps me realize that there are good, kind and caring people all over the world. It has motivated me to protect the environment so that future generations can witness the incredible beauty that is nature.

I am forever grateful for travel helping me open myself up to the opportunity to evolve as a human being. I\xe2\x80\x99m more compassionate and passionate because of the experiences that I have had." - @theglobetrottingaccountant, SkyMiles Member

How has travel impacted your life?'

b'"Even though kids are at home doing virtual classes, my goddaughter\xe2\x80\x99s school still had spirit week. Today was "I want to be a _____" day.  Meet Lilly, a future Delta Pilot." \xe2\x81\xa3\xe2\x81\xa3\n\xe2\x81\xa3\xe2\x81\xa3\nPhoto: Amanda B. - Scheduling Operations Manager, #ATL'

b'"Jets need love too \xe2\x80\x94 today I volunteered to help deep clean & sterilize one of our Delta planes. We bathed her & performed a top-to-bottom interior cleaning to ensure she\xe2\x80\x99s ready for our customers when they are ready for us. :airplane_selector: #DeltaProud"\xe2\x81\xa3\n\xe2\x81\xa3\nPhoto: Jamar H. - Network Planning MBA Associate, #ATL'
b"It's Happy Hour in the (virtual) Delta Sky Club!\n\nTap into our highlights to get the recipe for this week's drink, the Traveler's Mule."

b'"Travel is what makes me smile. It makes me excited to explore and find adventure. It\xe2\x80\x99s incredible seeing places around the world for yourself - photos will never do the real experience justice. And then you pinch yourself because your memories feel like dreams!

I miss the disruption to my routine. I miss the delicious food and the hikes that lead to beautiful escapes, like this waterfall! I\xe2\x80\x99m so grateful that travel has added so much color into my life. After all, this life is for thriving, not just surviving." - @manishapanjwani_, SkyMiles Member

What's your favorite travel memory?'
b"We're proud to share the sky with these jets as they salute first responders and healthcare workers on the frontlines of COVID-19. #KeepClimbingTogether\n\nPhoto: @kelleyelyons"

This week, tag us in your best photos from 30,000 feet and let\xe2\x80\x99s take flight together from home. #NationalPhotographyMonth

Photo: @tomkrobinson98"

b'To the moms who\xe2\x80\x99ve taken on new roles at home, the ones who are separated from family right now, and the moms at Delta who are still keeping us connected, thank you for always being there.\n\nFrom our family to yours, Happy Mother\xe2\x80\x99s Day!'

b'"I called Delta Air Lines to cancel a ticket booked to meet my daughter in Amsterdam. I asked the agent how she was doing.
\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80
Long pause..."not well." We talked a bit about what it must be like to have call after call of people crying and then going on the next and saying "how can I help you?" I jokingly asked her what I could do, maybe sing her a song. I was surprised when she said, "would you?\xe2\x80\x9d
\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80
So I went to my piano, put the phone on speaker and played her the first verse of a sweet song. To my surprise, I heard her singing along, somewhere in the call center.
\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80
During the verse, I could hear her choking up as she sang. Afterwards, she said that was her favorite song. I also teared up and we both talked about how it was all going to be alright, said "love you" to each other and hung up.
\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80
I'm still smiling about it, and I think she is too." \xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80
While our commitment to delivering a reliable customer experience hasn\xe2\x80\x99t wavered, it\xe2\x80\x99s nice to remember during these uncertain times that we\xe2\x80\x99re all just people - real people on the other end of a phone call or a tweet. Thank you to a customer for sharing this story with us.'

b'"Life is short and the world is wide! I believe that when you explore the world around you, you discover the world within you.

Travel opened my eyes and my heart to the world, to different people, and experiences that I am so grateful for. Traveling made me a better person. I look forward to the day where I can share that with my son again. When I can show him the world. :red_heart_selector::globe_showing_Americas: #skymilesmom" - @verbalgoldblog, Silver Medallion Member

What are you grateful for when traveling?'

b"Raise your hand if you wish you were drinking one of these in the Delta Sky Club right now.:raised_back_of_hand:\n\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\nHead to our highlights to learn how to make our Day Tripper Spritz. It's the perfect refresher before a long flight... or when you just need to treat yourself at home."

b'"I might be at a standstill right now, but my wings will be ready to fly again when we turn the page to a new chapter of this journey."\n\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\xe2\xa0\x80\nPhoto: Emily A. - Flight Attendant, #ATL'

Photo: @australiaunseen"

b'"This time a year ago I was looking at a castle, now I\xe2\x80\x99m just looking at a picture of myself looking at that castle and feeling deeply grateful I did the things when I had the chance to do them.

Travel means so much to me because it\xe2\x80\x99s changed me. It has replaced my ignorance with understanding. It has given me beautiful relationships that I treasure. It has broadened my perspective and taught me that there are many happy ways to live.

So...when this is all over, take that trip you\xe2\x80\x99ve always wanted to take. Reconnect with that family member or friend you have lost contact with. Be brave and do it." - @megthewanderess, SkyMiles Member

How has travel changed you?'

b'A few words of encouragement can go a long way.
